data.text: Contents
Introduction
Historically patients with Thyroid cancer have had a lifelong telephonic follow up. The purpose has been to confirm and ensure TSH suppression and to detect recurrence, if any.
Much data has accumulated on the risk categories of patients diagnosed and treated with Surgery and Radioiodine Remnant Ablation [RRA]. There will be a small group that have only surgery with no RRA.
Dynamic Risk Stratification (DRS) allows for a follow up based on risk of recurrence determined at 9-12 months after RRA.
It is planned that the nurse led telephonic clinic [and any face to face clinic] is held co-terminus with an oncology clinic [KSM/IA].
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To implement Thyroid cancer risk stratified follow up:
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Complying with the Data Protection Act 1998, General Data Protection Regulations 2018 and local and national guidance, policies and procedures for telephone follow ups.
Consultant
Ensure appropriate patients that are suitable for telephone clinic.
Ensure compliance with Trust policies, protocols and guidelines which apply to their roles within the hospital.
To review any patients that needs further review after Nurse Led Clinic.
Nurse for telephone clinic
Ensure completed competencies.
Ensure compliance with Trust policies, protocols and guidelines which apply to their roles within the hospital.
Ensure obtained consent for telephone clinic.
Ensure patient details are correct.
Ensure that all blood tests are reviewed prior to clinic with consultant.
Ensure that any concerns highlighted in the Consultation that the individual is book backed to a consultant clinic.
Key elements of the policy
Review of all KAM 1T clinic lists:
B. Contemporary Patients
Review of KSM 2M, IA HN clinic lists:
Low risk group: Telephonic FU; Target TSH low-normal range 0.3–2 mU/L. Discharge at 5 years.

Intermediate Risk group: Telephonic FU; Target TSH 0.1 and 0.5 mU/L for 5–10 years at which point the need for continuing TSH suppression should be re- evaluated with potential for discharge at 5 years.
High Risk group: This group of patients will continue within a consultant clinic Target TSH: below  mU/l indefinitely in the absence of specific contra- indications.
Other patients:
C. Consent
Consent from Patient in agreement for telephone follow up.
D. Patient inclusion criteria
a) Completed Radioiodine ablation
b) Undetectable or stable Thyroglobulin [Tg] levels at 9-12 months
c) Able to clearly communicate by telephone.
E. Patient exclusion criteria
a) Poor hearing.
b) Memory problems.
c) Known metastatic disease.
d) Hurthle cell carcinoma.
Actions:
a) Any rise of Tg from 9-12 months' consult with named consultant.
b) Any clinical concern, consult with named consultant.
c) Difficulty in optimising Thyroxine levels to be discussed with named endocrinology or oncology consultant.
F. Methodology / preparation
a) Patient booked into clinic – KSMTC
b) Clinic to run alongside consultant clinic and then moved to Tuesday afternoons, where a consultant is always available.
c) 8 weeks prior to telephone consultation blood form sent out to patient.
d) Ensure contact details are correct on Medway.
e) Check bloods results are available prior to telephone consultation.
G. During the nurse led telephone clinic consultation
a) To prepare the template, bloods results.
b) Consent and check patient identification details. (Name, DOB, address, GP details).
c) Check patient History, Medications and Allergies.
d) Check patient symptoms, if any, and record the answers on the template.
e) Check bloods results and discuss with patient.
f) Any changes in medication to be discussed with Consultant.
g) Changes in calcium replacement to contact Endocrine Consultant, and if needed book back into consultant clinic.
h) Arrange next follow up appointment, if agreed to continue telephone follow up.
H. After the nurse led consultation
Complete template and dictate letter. And send a copy to secretaries for uploading to CED and copy to GP10.2. Inform Consultants of patient who may need consultant follow up.
I. Changes in patient risk – back to consultant follow up
a) Any new lumps/ swelling reported by patient.
b) Non-compliance with medication/ telephone follow-up appointment.
c) Complex changes in levothyroxine/ calcium replacement dose.
d) Changes in Thyroglobulin.
e) Patient who fail to answer the telephone to rebooked for the next clinic
f) Patients after 2 failed appointments to be discharged back to the GP.
J. Discharging of patients
After 5 years with guidance for GP – TSH suppression range, risk of recurrence given to GP.
Training requirements
A. Nursing requirements
Knowledge of current BTA guidelines
An understanding of Thyroid hormones and suppression. As well as Knowledge of symptoms of hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism.
+/- non medical prescribing. (MMP013)
Completing competencies in changes of medications.
Competencies in adjusting Levothyroxine doses to ensure balance between achieving target TSH and Serum Free T4 levels
Access to ICE booking of Thyroid Function tests, Tg, and calcium.
B. Competency: Telephonic follow up

The initial 20 patients will be discussed with Oncology Consultant. If from this adequate experience is not obtained with regard to assessment and adjustment of medication a further 20 patients will be jointly reviewed
Thyroid and endocrine experience will be further gained from attendance at Endocrinology Consultant clinic.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the surgical/oncology governance, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Nurse Led Thyroid Clinics. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group. Once approved will be uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
It is the author's responsibility to inform surgical/oncology governance of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 1: BTA 2014 - stratified follow up
BTA 2014: TSH should be suppressed below 0.1 mU/l indefinitely in the absence of specific contra-indications

table_items.text: All the following Suppressed and stimulated Tg < 1 µg/L l* Neck US without evidence of disease Cross-sectional and/or nuclear medicine imaging negative (if performed)

Any of the following Suppressed Tg < 1 µg/L * and stimulated Tg ≥1 and <10 µg/L l* Neck US with nonspecific changes or stable sub centimetre lymph nodes. Cross-sectional and/or nuclear medicine imaging with nonspecific changes, although not completely normal
Any of the following Suppressed Tg ≥1 ug/l* or stimulated Tg ≥ 10 µg/L * Rising Tg values Persistent or newly identified disease on cross-sectional and/or nuclear medicine imaging

data.text: *Assumes absence of interference in the Tg assay. Key recommendations for TSH suppression:

For historical patients who have not undergone Dynamic Risk Stratification, it is recommended that serum TSH should be suppressed below 0.1 mU/l for 5–10 years. This suppression can then be relaxed as appropriate, based on clinical, radiological or biochemical assessment of response (4, D).
